div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,416] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Office of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, Every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindiel Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined sea and special train fare os 22.9.11 Port said to london via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent. on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London calling Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every altenate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.

row.cell: F.G. Davidson Superintandent P & O S.N Company in Egypt

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orontes" will leave Suez about February 9
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about February 23.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ormuz" will leave Port Said February 12
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Port Said February 26
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 0/0 if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about February 15.
S.S. Warwickshire 7,966 tons, leaves about March 1.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Shropshire 5,785 tons, leaves about February 19.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons leaves about March 4.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Tabor now on the berth, will sail on or about Wednesday, February 14, to be followed by S.S. Rameses.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about March 11 for Malta, Gibraltar &Devonport
S.S. AARACAN 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about March 15 for Liverpool

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son, (EGYPT), LTD

Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Halfa, and Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.
NILE STEAMER SERVICES
TOURIST SERVICE.- The large and splendidly appointed S.S. "Rameses the Great" will leave Cairo on Tuesday, February 13th for Luxor, Assuan and Philse.
ASSIUT SERVICE. First-class Tourist Steamers Amasls or Tewfik will leave Assiut every Tuesday for Luxor, Assuan and Philse. 14 days on the Nile including excursions for £35.
EXPRESS SERVICE. - Steamers leave Cairo every Monday and Friday for Luxor, Assuan and Philse. 19 days on the Nile for £22.

Special combined rail and steamer Nile Tours at greatly reduced fares. Bi-Weekly Service to Halfa, Khartoum and the Sudan. Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties. Regular service of freight steamers between Cairo & Halfa. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principle Railway Stations and landing places in Europe to pesist passengers holding their tickets. Tours to Palestine, Syria, and Desert. Best Equipment. Lowest charges.

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about17&31 January,February 14&28at 4 p.m.
Syrian. Caramanian Line
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about22 January,5&19 February4 p.m.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about29 January,12&26 February,4 p.m.
Far East Lines

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about February 3 and March 6 and April 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about February 9 and March 9. To Djibouti, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about January 20and February 20.
East African Line.
Departures from Suez: To Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay, Durban, about Febr. 3 and March 6andApril 3.
For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez, Thos. Cook & Son, Ld., Leon Heller, Cairo Agent, 4, Sharia Maghraby, (Telephone 192), Cairo; F. Tedeschi, Helouan.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:

From December 2nd until further notice the "Train de Luxe" composed exclusively of Sleeping and Restaurant Cars will every once Wednesday and Saturday at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor every Thursday and Sunday at the same hour. The Sleepers and Dining Cars will no longer be attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo and 5.30 p.m. from Luxor respectively.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday was cool and raw and as the day advanced the wind rose making the night fairly cold. To-day advanced the wind rose making the night fairly cold. To-day opens bright and clear with a strong Westerly breeze and a falling barometer. More wind is expected during the night.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
London Correspondent's Offices -36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices -No. 1 Sharia Zervudachi, (opposite Agricultural Bank.
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1906.

div.head: THE DREADNOUGHT.
div.p: THE DREADNOUGHT.

To-day a naw epoob begins in the history of naval «instruction, with the launching o the most powsrfol engine of deatrnotion the* baa ever been devised, for the Dreadnought, which will be laanohed by the King this afternoon ia a battleship potency. Whst will the Admiralty do with thi» ship of tremendous power when th, in commission and flying the white puiga I Wi'h her ten 12in. guns of the lst«v0^x. in oontrast with only four each '^‘espou mounted in even the best foreign battWhipa, ' ■be will be iqasl to »ny two vevsli new sflost Hrr broadside in s res fight will consist of the tire from no fewer than eight of these deadly pieces, and in defen-ivs qoili- tier, thanks to the thickness sud quality of her armour, the will be immuns ftnm damage by gutfire at ordinary battle rangs. The Atlantio Fleet is the •‘pivot” force of the navy, and oonaequently it is in the natoral order of thioga that his Majesty’s ship Dreadnought should be attached to this furoe, whidi is commanded by Vioe-Admiral Sir W. H. May. That Admiral's flagship, oommandgd by CapL A. C. Leveaon, at the late “battis prso- tioe," when steaming at fifteen knots, fiisd eleven shells from her fonr 19in. gnus and hit the target—nearly three and a half miles distant — ten times, discharged 81 rounds with her foar 9. Sin. gnus, making fifteao bits and soored 36 (lit* out of 71 rounds from ha 6in. gone. If the Dreadnought, with her ten 12in. gone, equals this record of tbs King Edward VII., she will pieroe the target oedtr similar conditions twenty times with bet devastating 8801b. shells. It is satisfactory to know that this vessel of unparalleled power is to be tha flagship of an officer who ia so keen on quick, straight shooting-thi ba-all and end-all of naval piepantion.

When the Dreadnought joins the Atleaiù Fleet ia the early months of 1907, this fora will be the most strategical unit which bai ret been placed under the orders of an admiral. Its creation a year ago was a stroke of geoim •iooe it enables the British Fleet to make CM of that invaluable Imperial heritage, Gibraltar, to the beat advantage. The “Book” is the bus of Admiral May’s oommand, whiob is thus midway between 8ir Arthur Wilson in tbs Channel and North Sea and Lord Charla* hereeford in the Mediterranean, with Malts y ois hcS8 pûst. Aï Rouble threatens oo the one side or on the other, »0, will S'? William May move his ships. It is the esgs»^ of war to eo place the most prwerfal npi'iof y in time of (esce that they may be of the greatest ose b time of war, whatever tbs particular character of the ooi fliot may be, acd whoever the enemy or enemies. Fur this as they are completed for sea thl battleships of the King Edward VII, type art attached to the Atlantio Pleet. .In no other navy are there vessels of snob Sooceotrstsd power of offenoe and defeuoe, and by the time the Dreadnought joins this oommàud Admiral May will have under h s control s force with- oat a rival on the world's seas.

In addition to the Dreadnought, the Atlantic Fleet will oomprise several battle hips of Hbt King Edward VII. type—eaoh mounting /oor 19b., fonr 9 9in, and ten 6iu. gone. Presuming that oiroomstanoea occurred which etabled each of these eight men-of %ar to put in a fall' broadside, every minute they would discharge shell of the following weights —
Ship». Weight ol shell
llbap
Dreadnought S.ÜOI
Sevan King Edward VII.'. SI,9*»
SS.TSi»

This oaloulat’on is based on the mod«t assumption that from eaoh 19in. gun one shell will be fired a minute, two from each 9.3». and five from every 6in. piece. These rates w* frequently exceeded, hot they «office as w iveragfl for a fjeet o( eight ibips Oo ’-is basis we get a total ditoharge each miuuU from the Atlantio Pleet firing broad.ide-ou »'• an enemy of over twenty six torn ôf meta'. and, presuming the standard of the King Edward Vll.’s 13in. guns can be maintained, .boot twenty-three tons would find s bom? » the ships of any foe who ohenoed to be the )bj«otlve.

Nothing as devastating as this oonceMrated Instruction has ever been oonceived in the hrab of man. it ia impossible to picture the etnlt of one minute’s well-directed tiro at an enemy’s ships, and when one minute is follovr- ed by others, the effeot would be tco terrible for words, presuming tha gobners get the range and fire as at target praotice. To this length has the contest for sea power gone, and this is r;ot the end, for the time, is »“*• far distant when the British ensign will dy over r aets and squadrons of Dreadnought1. cosa million and a half aterlii.g eaoh or mov each with ten or twelve 13 a- ons, which will engage an an’agonist when three or fonr miles distant, and will pour ia • saooession of shells, eaoh weighbg 850-h» oarrybg wholesale dei’.rootion in their w*k»,

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Lagislativa Council.
The Legislative Conncil will meeting on | on !5'b iai-t.
Savoy Dances
Henceforth th« 8->v>y Hotel will give two dancer fv-ry week during the aeaaon, on Tuesday as well as Saturday.
Al Aihar
jr ,» rumoured that the Cbanoellor of the University of Al Aehar has resigned, owing a d tTerence with the Council, of the Senate of that University.
Dangerous SwMts
A young Greek boy puroha»ed some oaramels at Alexandra two days ago and sucoumbed no.inafterw.rdi. The iweats ware bought from a street haaker.
Tha Nourel Bahr.
The "Aida” left Suez hurriedly on Wednesday evening for the 8outb, in search for the coastguard cruiser "Naur el Bahr,” which vessel is overdue at Sues shoe tome days.
Egyptian Institute.
There will be a meeting of the Egyptian Innitute on next Monday afternoon, when Dr. Apostolide* will lejture on the linraiatio and ethnological relations of the Pelasgians, Greeks and Albanians.
Exhibition at Cairo.

The inauguration of International Exhibition of Art will take place at the Cercle Artiatiqoe on Wednesday next, at X p.m. This year's ‘ Salon” promises to be very fine. It will be open to the pnbho o r and alter Thursday next. Coal imports.

From the 1st of January to the 8th of Pe- broaiy 9a,743 tons of ooal were imported into Egypt. Wales sect 66,537, Ntwoaatle . 6,784 Scotland 2, 7a6, Yorkshire 14,103, and other plaoes 60s tons. During the same period last year 60,663 tons were.
Land Deal at Alaxandria.

As a sample of the striking rise in land values at Alexandria, we m»y instance the ta a of Messrs, Hiushelwvod's property, opposite the European Hospital. It oonsista of abunt 4,0u> pics and Was bought three years ago for £t>,0 0. it was sold yra.e.d»y lor about £1 ,t On to the ‘‘Uibaii.es et Rurales” Company.
H.M.S, Diana.

H.M.S. Diana returned to Suez (rom Port Sudan ou Monday last. After ouating in the North basin she anchored u the Sues Roads. Captain R. S. Phipps-Hurnby, R.N., of H.M.S. Diana, accompanied by Mr. V. T. Hughes- Lateila, British Pro-Consul at Suer, paid an official visit to lurabiin Halim B y Governor of Suet, on Thursday last.
Lighthouses and the Weather.

The recording of meteoroiogioal observations as promised by the lighthouses in Egypt and the Red Sea will ne of great interest. Compared wi.h previous reoords, colitckd by government officiais and private initiative, a graphic representation will show whether the assertions of Older redden m, as to the onmate having altered in recent years, wi.l be norue out by aocurate scientific ohsei valions.
Helouan's Future.

The future prospecte of Helouan are still brightening. The price of tendis going up and there is no doubt that there wul tea boom tu the near future. The principal hotels are doi- g well, and the provision of new rolling stook fur the tatiwsy will le a great acquisition. The races have this ye»r been rxoeptiunally suooe*» ful and the prospects of the furthcoming meeting are most satisfactory.

Ths Egyptian Cotton Milla The manager of this company requests ns to state that the reports which have reoeotly appeared in the local Press with refereioe to it» reconstruction are erroueoos.No steps whatever have been taken in this direction as yet, and the statement made by the chairman at the recent general meeting held ia London was o ily in the nature of a suggestion, no motion bearing on it being put to the meeting Bishop Blyth's Visit.

In honour of the annual visit of the Bishop in Jerusalem and i he East, an entortainmeot will be given by the pnpils of 8t Mary’s Girl» School at 3 pm. on Monday next. Lord and Lady Cromer have promised to be present a' the entertainment, which will consist of an English play, a version of ths fairy story of the Sleeping Beao'y, and a French operet'a l»> Poole Noire, bishop Blytb, who will be -tvym, at St. Mary's Mission, will probably leave for LnxOr, Assouan and Khartoum on Tuesday next at à pm. He will spend a Sunday am - preach at each of there centres. Tomorrow morning the Bishop will preach at All 8ainto’ Cbareb,Cairo. Service will oommenoe at 10.30. Ball at Port Sala.

The Port Said Club gave a most suonesr :ul ball a lew days ago, largely attended by the leading members of the French, English, Italian and Greek communities. A uniqne feature was the introduction of a newly oomposed qnndrille, dan ed by a set «ho had oarefully rthar-ed the itepH. An exhibition of a cake walk and sand dance, given by Messrs. Tes’er a d Nogeut wa-*mu';h appreciated. It is pleaaing to see a greater tendency than of old, on the part of the different nationalities, to combine in social in etcoorse, amusement, and entertao • nient. The Panoy Dresi Ball, inaugurât* d by th-International Sporting Club at Port 8-id, promises to be a rentable ‘ universelle entente c irdiale," tickets having been largely sought sf e* by all and sundry, hailii g from p aces as fer disant ad Stornoway and Petersburg

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES
div.p: D is generally expected that Sir Bdward LAW, K C.M G., will mooeed Sir Vincent Cail- lard as ohairmao of the London agency of the National Bank ot Egypt in the eveut of the seleotion of Sir Vinoent as Sir Blwin Palmer’s suooessor as Governor of the National Bank b-ing fiaally ooofimed by Lord Cromer. Neither of these appointments have aa y t bean officially confirmed in Egypt, actirding to the late it information that has been received in the oity.

div.head: THE BANK'S DIVIDEND
div.p: A short time back a number of Jrws wbo were making a pilgrimage to the tomb of a celebrated Rabbi in the neighbourhood were attaoked by natives and a serious breach of the pesee ensue I. A number of the J'W- were hurt

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: We hear that among the recipients of the honours oonferre 1 by H.H. th* Khedive on tbs oocaaion of the anniversary of his aocession are, M. Emile Brngsch ou whom he rank of Mirmi- ran has been bestowed; Hassan Paoha Wasstf Mondir of Assiont also raised to the rank of Mirmiran ; Moh. A li Bey Charara, Mondir of Fayoom, Hassan Bey Hassib, Mondir of As souan, and Selim B. y Baoos, chief of the servioe of direct taxation to the Cairo Goavernorat on whom the grade of Moutemaiz has been be-towed and one of the principal officials of the Wakf* Administration, Ibrahim Bey H*- lim, Wakfs inspector at Damanhonr, who ba- received the same honour. Five native notabhs. among them Abd el Kader Bey el Gheriani, of Alrxandria, obtain the grade of Moutemaiz and five membdrs of the Legislative Conooil become Mirmiran s.

div.head: CAB STRIKES AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Alexandria presented a very tranquil appearance to-day owing to the complete absence of oabs, the cabmen baring oome out ou strike. The men demand the abolition of the municipal tax and the tariff, and also o implain of the system of ooutrol exercised over the cabmen by the Alexandria Goavernorat
Toe high Municipal a> d Goavernorat offi dais held a council and orna to a deo sion at 1 p m. this afternoon to meet m the oocrae of to day with the delegates uf thi cabmen.
The most jnst of the cabman’s grievances the fire minutes tariff fir half a frauo, which . ires scope to a great deal of abuse.
Au agreement will probably be arrived at by a slight i icrease iu some deuils of the tariff, which is low oompared with the high prices generally rating in Alexandria now.

div.head: BANK OF EGYPT
div.p: The net profits for the year, after providing f JI bad and doubtful debts, reba-e of interrs', outrent expenses in London and B/ypt,income- tax,a, and iooludiog £3 043 brought forward, amount to £148,907. The directors have trail-ferred £40,000 to reserve, and they recommend the payment of a dividend of 6 p.o. f r the half year, free of ioooue-tax, making, wi h he întmim dividend of 4 p.o. paid in July last. 10 p.o. for the year, »l-o a bonus of 8 p.o. (rOs per share), leaving £i 4,655 to be oarried forward.

div.head: ANTI-SEMITISM AT DAMANHOUR
div.p: National Bank shares rose on the Stock Exohange this morning, owing to romonrs of a possible inorease of two per oent in the dividend

div.head: THE WALL OF THE TIGRANES
div.p: Oo page 5 we give an aoooont of the for-h oomir,g pio endings in eonnection with the building of a wall obstructing the New Khédivial Hotel at Cairo. Ths facte, which are token from a Cairo contemporary, are very oarions and we mooh sympathise with Mr. Qeor geacoponlo, whose property will be seriously diminished in vaine, if the wall is allowed to remain.

div.head: YESTERDAY'S ECLIPSE
div.p: A total eclipse f the moon took place yo-terday morning, which was beit seen in America. At Greenwiob the moon set at hafpsst 7 o’olook, 17 miuntes bef.ro the middle of the eclipse, so that on'y the fir-t part of it was visible in E .gland It will be followed by a partial eclipse f the snn ne the 33rd. No part of this will be visible «•- Barone, and it will he best seen in 8iu'h I Amerios, end in New Zealand aud the Aoitra larian islands.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY
div.p: We understand that the negotiations now proceeding between the Khédivial Government and the Sublime Porte, in referenoe '0 the question of ths establishment of a Turkish post at Tarbah in ths Sinaitio Peninsula and on the Egyptian side of the frontier, are proceeding quite amicably.

It is stated, but we do not know upon what ground.», that a British orniaer is about to p\y a visit to the Gull of Akaba. Toe frontier which runs from a point north of Al Ariah to Akaba has never baen delimitated. It is hoped that the Turkish Government may be persuaded to send a boundary o >m mission in ooDjanotion with the Kbediyial Government so that the frontier line may be permanently settled.

div.head: ACCIDENT TO MOUHKTAR PACHA
div.p: We regret to state that Ghaci Monhktar Paoha met with an aoci lent yesterday, which alight have had moat serious oouscqaeaoe-. The Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner was paying a visit to his son and daughter-in- law at Bordeiu, when a passing train frightened the h irses. Thoy oo.ted and finally turned over the oarriage. The tteoha was hurled ti toe ground and severe y bruised. He also received a bad cat on tne lower lip. Owing to prompt medical attendance he isprooee ungfavourably.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES
div.p: A meeting cf the creditors of the Sucreries Company will be held at 3 o'clock to-day, and it is very probable that the proposals made under theConoordat Prevsutii wnlberead to the meeting. We understand that these proposals bave been drawn up, printed, and signed by the parties interested at Paris, from which place they arrived yesterday. Maître Carton do Wiart will probabiy read them to the m st- ing, unless the judge deotdee to prooeed to tha verification des titres."

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: Mr. Beckett, as a result of a thorough inspection which he has reoently made on the properties of the above Corporation, has been requested by the London Board to go home at once for the purpose ot oonanlting with them as to lhe immediate future ope ations and extensions, wUioh in Mr. Beckett’s opinion >h .old be undertaken without delay.
Mr. Beokett leaves by the P. aud 0. Mail on Sunday, and expeete to return before the end of the month.

div.head: IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENT
div.p: Mr. Binning, deputy chairmen of ths Liverpool Underwriters’ Association, speaking at the annual meeting at Liverpool last week referred to the great inoonvenienoe oansed to shipping by the disaster to the steamer Chatham, end the oonsequent delay neoessary for blowing her op. It was, he deolared, a question whether the time had not come to oonsider th» poesibi lity of donbliog the oanal, or outting a separate a

"This is only another plea for a teoond ial," remarked a leading City shipowner to a •‘Standard" représentative, "added to the many which have gone before. M. Binning gives an additional unsn»werable reason for the fai'h which it in him. When the Chatham sank she not only blocked the waterway, but menace to the oanal itself, for she had a large quantity of dynamite in her hold. 8he wa» got o .t of the way very expeditiously, on'y. I thiuk, about a week being oooupied in o'earanoa, whereas some of as had anticipated that the task would take a month. The operation was exceedingly well oarried out, and bat little damage WM done to the maL But brief as was the delay, it meant grievous loss to the shipping and mercantile oommnoity.

"This experience shows how easily a tingle oanal may be blooked either by accident or dasign. Bat there are other reasons why a second canal should be ont There is the defaooe of India to be oootidered. and on this point we are backed up by the highest military opinion. Faithermore, we know in praotioe that we have reached the limit of the oapacity of tha siogle oanal. The oong»stion becomes w >r*e every day, and we h»ve to faoe the dead ovrtainty of increasing delays in making the passage with our ships.
Lower Duea Required.

‘Another argument it that the ooet of transit through the existing oanal is absurdly High—more than donble as muoh as ikonght to be—and this is a great deterrent or impediment to Eastern trade. By reduoing the oanal dees one-half yon would immediately lower ths rate of oarriage from the Bast, and thereby enhanoe your trade. And there is no doubt that the does could be reduce 1.

I base this last assertion on the fsot that the oanal is enormously over oa pi tali ted, and yet is able to pay 80 per oent. from the profi’s— and this, in breach of a specific agreement entered joto^by the oompany with British shipowners, under which it WAS arranged that after paying v5 per oent all profi t should go 10 redno io i of duns.

'An addttoiial point to be considered is that a seoood canal oould be made for an infinitely leu exp nditara of oapital than was rvqiired for the firs' osna1, the Britiib Government giving a gnaran'ee—which it could do without risk—for a 5 per oent. dividend. Under sueha dividend ships oould be allowed through for one-third the present dues. LOOM end Aird, Jacks in, or any one of many contractors would, I am sere, readily undertake ths work. Yon would have contractors competing for it if the British Government took the matter up."
The Oppeelte View.

The oppoii'S point of view has been stated in an interview with a direotor of the 8urz Canal ooeupany which appeared in the ‘ Phoe- in wbich it w*t mentioned that the dividend was high but shareholders, being burner, desired to get at muoh *s they oould. Asked wbat be thought about the threat of a rival canal, the direotor repl ed that, io h;a opinion, the proposal was preposterous. F ran or, he said, owned £66,000.0'O of the share oaii- tel *.f ih» oanal the British Government nearly £34 O' 0,000 ; moreover, Great Britain was ths trn-tee of Etypt, to which the oanal would •vert in sevemy years: Th»t, he sd ■boaId be sufficient in itself. It was absurd >y that a iw n canal oould he constructed for £5,' 0»,000 Ttiis would be revised when it was remembered that not only would ths canal have to be made, but a port would h»ve to be created in the Mediterranean, another in the Red Sea. Tbe direotor, aom- ming op the whole nutter, declared that the agitation for a seoood canal would only have the effect of putting op tha baoks of the French shareholders, by which fntnre concessions might be endangered.

Con 6 mat ion of there views wa* obtained in iibir q i r er* by :be 'Standard." One authority deolared, ‘ 1 never looked on the agitation lor increased canal f cilities as in any way •ariooa, and I *h >nld be surprised to bear that there are many people who understand ths question who are not of my opinion.”

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY- CRICKET
div.p: Excellent weather prevailed on Monday last for tha annoal Boy ram match at Ghesireh ground and a number of people wars attracted to the orioket during the afternoon.

Alexandria won the tost and elected to bat, opening their innings with H. B. Carver and Byroe ; ths latter however soon snooumbed to the wily slows of Stoat, who proved too mach for most of the Alexandria tide. It was not till H. P. Carver joined hit brother that any stand was made againt t the bowling, bat H. B. Carver was shortly after dismissed by Stoot for 18. H. P. Carver oontinaed to olay a good steady innings, but rone of the Alexandria!’s were able to assist him. Main prioe and Macaalay were both oanght at the diffioalty before the lunch interval, leaving
H. P. Carver with an no finished 60, ont ot a total of 116.

Cairo started batting with much greater confidence than the visitors. After the fall of one wicket, Patin and Anderson settled down to fast sooring, the latter being fiaally bowled by H. B. Carver for 51. Paton oonti- uned hi» hard hitting and with tha low of two wickets the Alexandria total was pasned ; at 4.80 the innings was deolsred dosed with 356 for 7 wiokete. Paton having been oanght in the loDg field for a well earned 9o. Cor the visitors H. B. Carver obtained 6 wiokete, being the only bowler who eonld maintain his length.
Alexandria batted again for } hoar making 67 for 3 wiokete, H. B. Carver carrying his bat for 45. Scores :

div.head: ST ANDREW F.C. ROYAL GARRISON ARTILLERY F.C.
div.p: The above teams met on Saturday last on Moharrem Bey Common, and in spite of th*> inclement weather there were several spectator». The game throughout was very evenly contested, beth end» being visited in torn. Good play was shown by individual member* of both aides, but sll efforts to score were fruitless. The teams orrued over without interval, and the aecoud half was stubbornly contested. No sooting took plaoe, and the game thna ended in a goal-lees drew.
Th» following were the team» :—
Royal Garrison ArtiUsry F. C.—Sullivan, Holme», Bowler Hart, Chapman Coodiffe Croat Fryer Burke H. Davie», and Cromp.
St Andrssc F. C. Webb, Keill, Curtis, Metzger Cowie, Rofa, Constantinidii, Timer, La'k, Jones, and Dowdall.

To-day the 8t Andrew P. 0. are the gneate of the Vietoria College F.C. This is the third meeting of the team* this season, the first game having ended in e draw, end the teoond going to the College XI. by the odd goel. A good game ebon Id be witnessed. Kiok off 8 p.m.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: It is probable that among the visitors coming to Egypt shortly will be the Grand Doohess Vladimir, the Grand Dake' Boris, and tbs Princess cf Hohenlohe Langeobnrg, who have 'eftCanDM fora croise in the Mediterranean cn the steam ysoht Margarita.
Among tha latest distinguished arrivals at the Savoy Hotel are the Hon. Arthur Stanley, Lady Bougbey, Major Pirie, and the Hon. Sidney Pad.

Among those who have left Eogland for aises in the Mediterranean, and who will io all probability visit Egypt in the near fntnre, are the Duke of Leeds in his yaoht the Aries, and Sir Charles Elliot in the Dews.

These hotels are excellent, considering that they are oft tha beaten traok, for although the charms of the Payoum are beoom:ng better known, tourists do not flock to that most in- teresring part ot Egypt in the numbers they
Mr. sod Mrs. H. K. Baynes have arrived in Cairo and are staying at Cecil Flats, Boulao Avenue. Mr. Bay net it the managing Direotor of the Bgyptian Engineering Company, Limited.
Mr. C. S. Cade, who is an official in Cyprns, and Mrs. Cade, are visiting the interesting ament of Upper Egypt.

Capt. and Mrs. Doherr are at present on a holiday tonr in Egypt. Many friends of the popular oommodore of the D. 0. A. line will learn with pleasure that he will shortly take command of the new steamer "Princesrin,” the now-completing sister ship to the “Admiral.”
